intro: Ranunculus villosus, commonly known as the hairy buttercup, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to Europe and western Asia. It features showy, bright yellow flowers with five to eight petals, often surrounded by a ring of sepals. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, with hairy stems and leaves that are deeply lobed and covered in fine pubescence. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows, woodland edges, and stream banks. The hairy buttercup is part of the Ranunculaceae family, known for its distinctive floral structures and often toxic compounds.
